position.marginalia_text: Entelechia[e] semper opus purificato animo, et spiritu illuminato.

marginalia.translation: Every purified mind and illuminated spirit needs actualization.

position.marginalia_text: Sola ferè apophthegmata, epigra[m]mata, sales, et stratagemata dicunt, aguntq[ue] adamantinè: cu[m] ipsis Legibus, et Armis.

marginalia.translation: In general only aphorisms, epigrams, witticisms, and stratagems say and act as adamantine: with the laws themselves and arms.

position.marginalia_text: Nisi quòd ipsa[e] Artes, et Virtutes, omnium dicendoru[m], agendoru[m]q[ue] magistra[e] peritissima[e], subtilissima[e].

marginalia.translation: Unless because the arts and virtues themselves are the most skillful and subtle teachers of everything which must be said and done.

position.marginalia_text: Eudromi singulare Mnemosynon: Et exquisitiss[im]us singulorum; et omnium expeditissimus.

marginalia.translation: A singular remembrance of Eudromus. And the most exquisite of singular things, and the most prompt of all.

position.marginalia_text: Eutrapeli anima, candidissima omnium anima: Eudromi ingenium, nitidissimum Mundi ingenium. Illa etiam omnium alacerrima, Sine vlla Nubecula: hoc Mundi viuidissimu[m], sine vlla hebescentia aut tepore. Quarum neutrum potest consistere sine aurea
dia[e]ta: adamantina exercitatione: et angelica semper illuminatione omniu[m] animi, corporisq[ue] potentiaru[m].

marginalia.translation: Eutrapelus' mind is the most lucid mind of all: Eudromus' intellect, the most polished intellect of the world. That [mind] is also the most eager of all, without any troubled expressions. This [intellect] is the most lively of the world, without anything growing blunt or any mildness. Neither of which can consist without a golden regimen, unflexible exercise, and always angelic illumination of the mind and body of all powers.

position.marginalia_text: et Apollonij dicta, factaq[ue] omnia adamantina. Rarissima scripsit et Semper breuissimè.

marginalia.translation: Too bittle, but childish: a divine axiom, and the sayings and deeds of Apollonius are all incorruptible. He wrote the most rare things and always most concisely.
